segments.text: Certainly, here's the translation of the provided Hebrew text into English.
She didn't know her at all.
One evening, she met her in the parking lot at the entrance to the pink house when she returned with Rolf from a movie.
As they got out of his car, a small mini-minor stopped next to them, and Joseph and the lady who was driving it got out.
Meet her, he said.
She shook the lady's hand and heard her say in English.
Nice to meet you.
I've heard a lot about you from your father.
Interesting, she thought, on the other hand.
I haven't heard anything about you.
She glanced at her sideways and saw a not-young, thin woman, without a trace of charm, but meticulously dressed, conveying classic taste.
It was less than a month before her enlistment, before she lost her home.
One evening after that, her father told her that he was getting involved with the lady, and would live with her in her apartment in Tel Aviv.
That would be their new home.
He didn't give her details, like who she was, when and how they met, and how it was that he was already moving in with her.
He simply stated it as a fact.
On her first leave from the army, she came to their apartment in central Tel Aviv, and there, in the corner of the living room, stood her piano, and on it was the teddy bear Rolf had left her to hug.
The piano slightly comforted her, gave her a kind of home feeling, but nothing beyond that.
A small room on the side was allocated for her.
It didn't bother her to speak English.
The language was fluent for her, but something in the lady's style and tone conveyed a very clear message.
You're a guest here.
Don't get confused.
From the very first moment, she felt their estrangement and alienation, and she was glad that she didn't have to stay there more than two or three days every two weeks.
She felt embarrassed seeing and hearing her father currying favor with his new partner and trying to appease her in everything.
It was clear to her that he was also a guest in his partner's life.
As time went on, it became clear that she wasn't entirely balanced, one moment entirely sweet, and the next proving everyone wrong at the gate.

This went on for several months until she received a letter in the army written by her father, asking her at the lady's request if she had possibly taken a blue towel with her to the army that was hanging in the bathroom.
She was shocked.
What would she need her towel for?
She had plenty of army towels.
And even if she did, how did this become an unforgivable crime?
It was more than insulting.
But mainly, she was offended by Joseph, her father, for stooping so low and not being ashamed to ask her such a question.
Two weeks later, she arrived at their apartment for another vacation from the army and found them sitting on the balcony with an open wine bottle, half empty.
She had no doubt that the lady of the house was drunk.
They started small talk and suddenly the lady asked her if there were any nice boys in her army unit.
When she answered that there weren't really, she received a cynical look, followed by the statement that tipped the scales.
It doesn't matter anyway, because you have a goy complex, hinting that Rolf wasn't Jewish.
It was so embarrassing and surreal that even Joseph objected.
What nonsense?
How can you talk like that?
Leora lifted her head and looked at his partner with sadness, almost pity, wondering who this strange woman was and what she was doing there in her company.
From that moment, she knew she wouldn't stay there any longer.
She felt that even Joseph understood that they had reached a point of no return.
The next morning, very early, she packed clothes and a pair of shoes into a bag, quietly left without arguing, but also without saying goodbye and never returned to that house.
This is how Joseph and her meetings began at Jackie's Cafe at the edge of the Boulevard.
Joseph almost ran to Jackie's Cafe at the corner of Chen Boulevard.
He feared he was late.
But it turned out his daughter hadn't arrived yet.
As soon as he sat down, Jackie placed a beer glass in front of him.
Are you waiting?
For your beautiful daughter, he asked.
Yes, she should be here soon, a bit late, he replied, glancing at the other patrons in the cafe and nodding hello to one or two familiar faces.
He took a long sip of his beer, feeling how its familiar bitterness was pleasant to his throat.
That's how he liked his beer, cold and bitter.
For a moment, an image of her appeared before his mind's eye, a skinny girl in shorts and a tank top pouring beer behind the bar.
Tilting the glass so no foam formed as he taught her, his heart ached inside him.
He was about to tell her that the long legal process in the Pink House story was finally over and they would finally be released the few pennies left from its sale.
But the image that appeared in him shook him, taking him back to the days when everything began to fall apart and he lost his way a bit.
This was a time he felt a kind of distance from her.
She was a bit cold towards him, less forgiving, as if she distanced herself so she wouldn't be too angry, and her silences echoed in his ears and especially in his heart.
Two weeks ago, he wrote her a long letter in the army, asking her to go back to being his girl, sharing everything with a sparkle in her eyes.
He reminded her she could tell him everything.
He loved her so much.
But deep down, he knew there was justice in her feelings.
He failed back then, leaving her to be the responsible adult when she was not yet 17.
During that period, he became addicted to wandering in the big city, trying to heal his heart and the anger he felt about the injustice and wrong in losing the house, maybe even ashamed before Lucy.

He felt then as if she was watching over and seeing how their life's work was destroyed, their life's work, and the fact that it happened mainly because of her oldest daughter didn't change his feeling.
For months he would disappear for a day or two, as if looking for occupations and pleasures until his anger subsided a bit.
Then he would return and find the house clean and tidy as if Lucy had returned for a visit.
Leora, his daughter, wouldn't say a word to him.
Just look at him with sadness, wonder, lack of understanding, as if trying to understand where her dad had gone, the one who ruled everything, who made sure everything worked, as he would say.
But it only worsened since he joined his partner after the pink house period and moved in with her in Tel Aviv.
They didn't quite get along, and he knew it wasn't due to his daughter.
He didn't know much about her before he joined her.
Maybe he rushed a little too quickly, understanding it would solve many problems at once, including where to lay his head the day after.
For a while, she would still come to sleep at their house, trying to fit in.
Her piano stood in the corner of the living room, and on it sat the proud teddy bear that Rolf had left her to hug.
He thought it would make her happy and give her a sense it was also her home.
But gradually, his partner revealed herself as having strange qualities, making embarrassing remarks towards his daughter, perhaps out of jealousy of her youth, her talents.
Leora began feeling uncomfortable in her company, and at some point, she simply got up and left the house quietly with a small bag of clothes in hand, unclear where to.
He knew that when she was out of the base, she stayed at friends' houses.
He hid this from his partner and told her she got housing in the army.
Since then, Jackie's cafe, less than a hundred meters from his home, became their meeting place.
In a cafe, he meets his daughter.
What a disgrace.
How did he not manage to build her a new nest where she would feel at home?
How does he continue asking her to tell white lies for him that long ago changed their color?
No wonder she distances herself from him, harbors anger towards him, and perhaps more than anger, disappointment.
She was his biggest admirer since she was born.
She would follow him around when he went to meet friends in the center, sit on his knees, listen to the gossip, or sit at his feet and be engrossed in her activities while he stood and painted.

Aside his easel, gradually she grew and became wise, discovering a talent for interacting with people, delighting in her musical talent on her piano, reading endlessly, turning into a girl any parent would be happy to have, seeing and hearing everything.
internalizing as if she knew the moment would come when she would have to mature all at once and leave her childhood behind before it was over.
Simultaneously, she began looking at him.
She understood he couldn't take care of her needs and she had to sort things out on her own.
I didn't even stop for a moment to think how she manages, he thought, releasing a deep sigh from his throat.
He sank completely into his thoughts.
When he lifted his head, he saw her on the boulevard, walking upright toward him.
He was so proud of the ranks on her shoulders, and even from afar he noticed the blue of her eyes.
She smiled at him a genuine smile, unreserved.
Forgetting the frictions between them for a moment and leaped into his arms.
As soon as they sat down, Jackie stood by them.
Your milkshake is already on the way with lots of vanilla just as you like.
He smiled at her.
Thank you, Jackie.
She returned a warm smile.
A girl and her father meet on the street in a cafe.
There's no other place.
It shouldn't be this way.
A few minutes earlier, she was still walking quickly along the boulevard, knowing she was a little late.
She couldn't leave the base earlier, hoping he was waiting for her and hadn't given up and left.
She was a bit angry at him.
For all the hot cold in his relationship with his partner, who he decided to leave more than two months ago, then changed his mind and sent her a letter detailing he decided to make another attempt.
And he asked her very much to cooperate with it, even if she thought he was wrong.
Asking her not to mention he gave her a few liras to say she got Arnie lodging and not as it actually happened since she decided she couldn't bear the lack of balance of his partner anymore.

She left quietly without making an issue with the firm knowledge that she didn't want to disrupt his life, but also out of a complete lack of understanding of what her special father was doing with such a strange woman who wasn't even beautiful.
In retrospect,
She understood that what primarily brought them together was the roof over his head she provided until he could find work to his liking.
Jackie's cafe became their meeting place every two weeks, half an hour, no more than a hundred meters from his home.
More than once, she noticed he would glance back in case his partner would emerge and catch him in the act.
But really, why?
Isn't he allowed to meet his daughter?
And still, she missed him, her dad that she loved so much.
The only parent left to her.
How did it happen that he suddenly became corrupted and became almost someone else?
Someone who asks her to lie, not really caring that she's staying each time somewhere else.
Several times she almost started to tell him about the arrangement with Yehuda, and each time something held her back, afraid he would be offended, angry, not handle it properly.
He had no idea that for several months she had a place, so she didn't understand how he wasn't worried about her.
He isn't worried because he trusts me completely, she justified to herself.
Since she was born, he would say, I have a daughter with common sense, a child with good sense, who knows how to distinguish between right and wrong.

Without feeling, a smile spread across her lips when she saw him at the cafe's corner and already she was in his arms, forgetting for a moment the little angers and wonderment she had about his conduct.
She so needed a father to know she was first in his life before anything else.
She so wished to be his little girl again who didn't need to worry about anything.
She wanted him to understand, too, that a hug is wonderful, but it is so insufficient.
Joseph dawned a serious expression and looked deeply into her eyes, diving into them, feeling the stormy sea within her, immediately knowing she was not as usual.
After all, he knew how the colors in her eyes changed with.
Every mood.
Now their color turned dark and somber for a moment, almost like the sky's two minutes after sunset.
Then, suddenly, she looked at him gently reconciled, forgetting what angered her, and around her pupils that beloved color spread, like with a deep blue marker, seeking to calm.
He took a deep breath and said, I need to tell you something.
I also need to tell you
The two girls, she and her half-sister, Lucy's daughter from her first marriage, each received 2,000 liras from the hotel sale, and that the money was supposed to go into her bank account.
When I think about how I wanted to take a loan and give her 10,000 liras almost three years ago, and it wasn't enough for her, what did she gain by destroying our lives?
Three years of legal discussions, total destruction of the house, and even more of the soul.
Without thinking, she threw you into the street, and all this for two thousand liras.
Leora sat across from him, not letting the words sink in.
She blocked them from touching her raw nerves, almost becoming numb.
Instead, she heard herself saying in a hollow tone, Great, it'll give me a breather until I start receiving full officer's pay.
He looked at her with pain, not understanding her response.
She softened all at once in response to his astonished gaze and quietly added, leave it, daddy.
It's too painful.
What's there to dig about?
